bibl.idno: The Philip S. Hench Walter Reed/Yellow Fever Collection [manuscript] / [collected by] Philip S. Hench ; HEALTHSCI MS-1.

div1.p: Telegrams to the War Department report deaths caused by yellow fever from May 8 to May 30, 1900. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Report of deaths, June 1900
div1.p:
OFFICE OF ADJUTANT GENERAL
JUN 5
326817
1900
WAR DEPARTMENT

328173 A.G.O. herein,
Maj Gen Leonard Wood
Camdg Div. Cuba.

Cables report of deaths
from May 20" to May
31", (inc.)- including one
death on May 8 - 1900.

Corrected Copy - of
Ext as to pack-
master Pieburn [unclear]
for Qing June 8, 1900
[unclear]

M. & R. Div., A. G. O.
JUL
18
1900
Cleaned up & filed.

CABLE MESSAGE.
THE WESTERN UNION TELEGRAPH COMPANY.

All CABLE MESSAGES received for transmission must be written on the Message Blanks provided by this Company for that purpose, under and subject to
the conditions printed thereon, and on the back hereof, which conditions have been agreed to by the sender of the following message.
THOS. T. ECKERT, President and General Manager.

Adjutant General's
OFFICE.
June 3 1900
ROLLS DIVISION.
[unclear]

TWO AMERICAN CABLES FROM NEW YORK TO GREAT BRITAIN.
CONNECTS ALSO WITH FIVE ANGLO-AMERICAN AND ONE DIRECT U. S. ATLANTIC CABLES.
DIRECT CABLE COMMUNICATION WITH GERMANY AND FRANCE.
CABLE CONNECTION WITH CUBA, WEST INDIES, MEXICO AND CENTRAL AND SOUTH AMERICA.
MESSAGES SENT TO, AND RECEIVED FROM, ALL PARTS OF THE WORLD.

OFFICES IN AMERICA:
All Offices (21,000) of the Western Union Telegraph Company and its Connections.

LONDON:
No. 21 Royal Exchange, E. C.
No. 109 Fenchurch Street, E. C.

LIVERPOOL: No. 8 Rumford Street.
GLASGOW: No. 29 Gordon St. and No. 4 Waterice St.
BRISTOL: Backhall Chambers.

RECEIVED at WAR DEPARTMENT,
6 CO J KN Government.

Death report twentieth to thirtyfirst May Columbia Barracks
Quemados First Class Sergeant Charles E Sherwood Signal Corps died
thirtyfirst Yellow Fever Private Frank EBlick E First Infantry drowned at
PinarDelRio May twentyeighth Santiago Packmaster James J.M. Pieburn died
at ElCaney May eighthseventeenth Pernicious Malaria Santa- Clara- Post Commissary

NOTED: RETURNS, A. G. O.,
9
C

LONDON:
No. 21 Royal Exchange, E. C.
No. 109 Fenchurch Street, E. C.

LIVERPOOL: No. 8 Rumford Street.
GLASGOW: No. 29 Gordon St. and No. 4 Waterice St.
BRISTOL: Backhall Chambers.
Sergeant Edward Murphy died twentyfifth Yellow Fever.

ADJUTANT GENL'S OFFICE
JUN 4 1900
A.G.O. DIVISION.

NOTED: RETURNS, A.G.O.,
9
Corrected copy sent Q. M. G.
June 8/1900.

Q. M. G.
Surg. Genl.
Maj. Baird
Col. Carter

Mr. Heitman
Mr. Staffard

GLASGOW: No. 29 Gordon St. and No. 4 Waterice St.
BRISTOL: Backhall Chambers.

Adjutant General,
OFFICE.
JUN 6 1900
ROLLS DIVISION.
[unclear]

In telegram of third instant read Frank Blick instead of
Frank Elick E First Infantry.

Cablegram third instant reports death James J. Piehurn, packer,
May eighth at El Caney. Name not found. Is this identical with
James M. Pieburn, packmaster, reported by Assistant Surgeon Fowler
as died May seventeenth.

CABLE MESSAGE.
THE WESTERN UNION TELEGRAPH COMPANY.

All CABLE MESSAGES received for transmission must be written on the Message Blanks provided by this Company for that purpose, under and subject to
the conditions printed thereon, and on the back hereof, which conditions have been agreed to by the sender of the following message.

TWO AMERICAN CABLES FROM NEW YORK TO GREAT BRITAIN.

30

No. 21 Royal Exchange, E. C.
No. 109 Fenchurch Street, E. C.

LIVERPOOL: No. 8 Rumford Street.
GLASGOW: No. 29 Gordon St. and No. 4 Waterice St.
BRISTOL: Backhall Chambers.

Adjutant General's
OFFICE.
JUN 7 1900
ROLLS DIVISION.

James J. Pieburn reported died May eighth is identical with James
M. Pieburn Packmaster died May seventeenth latter name and date
is correct.
